description: Encompasses the rights of persons accused of crime, except for the due process rights of prisoners.

Includes non-First Amendment freedom cases which pertain to classifications based on race (including American Indians), age, indigency, voting, residency, military or handicapped status, gender, and alienage.
The First Amendment guarantees freedoms concerning religion, expression, assembly, and the right to petition.
Limited to non-criminal guarantees. The promise of legality and fair procedure: before depriving a citizen of life, liberty or property, government must follow fair procedures.
Includes privacy, abortion: including contraceptives, right to die, and Freedom of Information Act and related federal or state statutes or regulations.

Attorneys' and governmental employees' or officials' fees or compensation or licenses, commercial speech, admission to a state or federal bar, disbarment, and attorney discipline, admission to, or disbarment from, Bar of the U.S. Supreme Court.
encompass those issues involving labor union activity.
Commercial and business related; it includes tort actions and employee actions vis-a-vis employers.
Concerns the exercise of the judiciary's own power.
Pertains to conflicts and other relationships between the federal government and the states, except for those between the federal and state courts.
Contain three types of disputes which occur between or among states.
Concerns the Internal Revenue Code and related statutes.
Contains three groups of cases that do not fit into any other category.
Relates to disputes between private persons involving real and personal property, contracts, evidence, civil procedure, torts, wills and trusts, and commercial transactions.
